And the wholesale customers, we have a very interesting system. I don't get this from everybody, because some of them are jealous to give us the database. But we have so called sales reductions. If you give us the sell-through information and you accept to make an automatic replenishment means that we deliver automatically a product the moment it has been sold out so that you have a good assortment, you get 1 or 2% better conditions from us. And we have a range of countries and retailers that immediately bought into this program. I can tell you, Xin Yu in China, he gives us all the sell-out information, and by the way since we are shareholders, I get also the sell-out information from all our competitors. It's legitimate. We are a shareholder and we have a seat in the Board of Directors. And we get from some countries in Europe, United Kingdom, for example, from the major retailers, I get sell-out information, not of all because some of them are refusing to give us the information. They have not understood that it's good for them that we know what's happening so we could help them to have the right assortment.

And that's one of the tendencies and of the push that we're doing to convince the retailer, give us the information, we accomplish a work for the assortments and you will do better businesses and we will do better businesses. So we encourage this with a certain form of 1 or 2% additional margin if he is doing this with us. And for the moment, I think about 20 to 30% of the wholesale retailers are doing this with us. The others are still reluctant; they are old fashioned. They say you have not to look into my books.
Okay. So is that mostly US and the rest of Western Europe?
Yeah. The US are not the most open retailers. But we have one big partner in the US who is giving us a look into the sell-out.
Tourneau, I guess. Okay.
I absolutely will say nothing about that.
Okay. And breakdown of inventories, could you give us sense of the spilt, is -- it is still roughly 25 --
Yes. The Geiser will exceptionally because we had not many ladies today so he will give you the spilt.

Okay. If you compare the two numbers in the balance sheet consolidated. I'll give you the increase by category as opposed to what we showed in our details in the annual report. Raw material, works-in-process and semi finished products this is what is in course of production has increased by CHF 142 million, finished goods by 101, mainly due to filling up or directing stock into the retail stores for the high selling period in summer and the openings of new retail stores. And also the customer service inventories have been increased under the light of new products being launched, being ready to service all those products by another 15 million. So these are the CHF 258 million that has been added to those individual categories.
Great. Thank you very much.
Thank you. Next question.
The next question is from Thomas Chauvet, Citigroup. Please go ahead sir.

Yes. Sorry, two quick follow-up questions. One with regards to production; your internal sales in H1 were up 16% versus only 4% for external sales, I mean, I understand the bottlenecks, I understand your strategy to give priority to your own brands. But can you tell us, if there has been any change in the way you allocate the available movements between your own brands and your competitors?

Mr. Chauvet, I would be happy, if we would be able to do this. But we would be in a hell of situation. No, I try to explain it. Swatch and Omega stands for the increase. You know Swatch is produced by ETA, nobody else gets product from Swatch. We are not obliged to deliver to anybody else. And Omega has own movements that they developed on themselves and they have a contract. ETA has to produce them. And these two brands are accounting for the major part of the increase in the production at ETA, if you compare third parties with us. This is the reason for it.
Okay. Thank you.
It's not to give advantage. You know, if we could we would give 100% only to our brand.

Thank you. And my second question with regard to the importance of tourism to your business, you've given the example of Russian tourists in Italy, earlier. Can you maybe give us your best estimates of the overall contribution of tourists to European sales and to US sales, if you've got an estimate, rough estimate?

I don't have one, but you see the tourists at the same time are also consumers of the product in their own country because they love the brand and they go outside of the country and they buy it outside; for whatever reason, either they don't have the product, they don't have a point of sales nearby or the prices are different. They want to take advantage of exchange rate fluctuation. So this is a number that is very difficult to get. In Switzerland we know that certainly a big part of the sales are done because of tourists in this country. But I cannot tell you how much.
Okay.
It would be pure speculation and I don't want to.
Thank you.
Thank you, next question?
Next question is from Louise Singlehurst, Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead, madam.

Hi, good afternoon. I wondered if you could just give us a bit of color on the general mood of your wholesalers and clients by region and how that has changed over the last few months if at all? And how your relationship has changed with them over recent years, i.e. how you control the level of discounting that happens within those wholesale outlets?

That's an interesting question Louise. So first of all, the mood is good, we have some of the retailers in Beijing invited and they follow the Olympic games. So I must say most of the retailers and the ones that are not watching too much business TV, CNBC or Bloomberg, are not reading too much analysis from the financial community. They are good -- have a good mood.

The mood is generally fine, but there are some areas in the world and I agree if I take the United States and the United Kingdom where retailers are owned by groups, by financial funds. The moment you have funds or you have a company that's in the stock market quarter, the tendency is that if they hear bad news from whatever area, they start to say, we have to decrease the stock, decrease the stock and this is especially in the Anglo-Saxon countries the case. And what we always have to do then with the retailer, we go through this exercise and we say look, you -- if you decrease your stock, you have good stock and bad stock. We can prove you if you have the right assortment, you sell more. And we have more and more retailers that understand this, but we have more and more funds and financial investors that are coming and they are looking just at the numbers and say your stock must go down, the moment there are some signs of whatever crisis. And here it's typically Anglo-Saxon countries. The rest of the world, the mood of the retailers is "Where the hell is my product? Please deliver, I want more". This is the mood that we see at the moment. In the rest of the world, Anglo-Saxon countries, a little bit more difficult.
The second question was, Louise, remind me?
It was just relationship that you've got with them and how that's changed are you -- can you control level of discounting that they're giving?

Yeah, discounting is a headache, I agree. We went now in China and Hong Kong more and more into a zero discount level with Omega. And of course, the strength of your brand together with your own distribution network permits you to control the discounting. And one way of controlling the discounting is reducing the margins to the retailer. Because why should I give to the retailer 40% margin, if he gives 15% away to the consumer? So I cut him his discount, I cut him his margin.

And that's what I forgot the reduction in margin for the retailer in some parts of Asia has also helped to increase our operating margin in the first half. That's what I forgot to say before. That has certainly a small impact.

And that's what we continue to do. We will supervise what is done with the brands, because it's extremely damaging to the brands. We will reduce margins and we will put our own stores nearby, if necessary to control the discounting policy. But you know the European Union is difficult. You cannot tell the retailer what pricing -- you can suggest him a price, but you cannot tell him he must sell to this price. But the tendency is reduction of this bloody discounting. But that's an effort the whole industry is trying to do.
And then just two very quick questions. Spain, obviously is tough for everybody.
Yep.
But is that the only market in negative territory? I mean how...?
No, there is another one, Australia.
Australia. And Japan, how is that performing?

Look, Japan, we have a number -- we are plus, we are growing. It's 2% or 3%. It's a small number. Of course, it's for everybody the same. I have even seen other companies that are having minus two, minus three, minus five. We are growing in small steps. But it's true. Japan is -- we don't see any signs of improvement. It's just going on like this. Perhaps we can only hope that there are many Russian and Chinese tourists coming to Japan to back my – the consumption over there. But it's not a preoccupation. We use this situation to clean the market, to position our brands better, to make everything what you have to do, to have a good start the moment the economy picks strongly up. At one point of time perhaps I don't know, in 30 years, Japan will be back on track. But if we grow, our two, 3% and the rest of the world is growing the way it's growing now, it's fine.
Great. And then very last question. Can you tell us when you'll start the rollout of the new Tiffany branded stores?
Yeah, first we have to roll out the product before we roll out the stores. So 2009 will be the rollout of the collection and you will certainly, also in 2009, see in one city, one of these stores.
Right.
So during the year 2009. We'll not tell you where the store could be, but it will be in Europe somewhere.
Great. Thank you.
Okay. Thank you Louise, so we will continue for another 10 minutes and at 4 o'clock we will cut. Next question.
The next question is from Julie Saussier, J.P. Morgan. Please go ahead madam.
Hi. Looking at the press release on page nine, the cash flow statement, can you explain why the cash flow from operating activities is down 35%?
Mr. Geiser.

I can explain. This is what the other gentlemen wanted to know with regards to the charges and taxes and all these payments and I have to reinforce once again what I said before. These are not add backs to the cash flow, these are payments to the large extent and this is one of the reasons when you used up also some cash in the increase in net working capital, I just explained also the increase in the inventory. And for good reasons, which is about 11%, 11.4 exactly. So this is all something in which we invested into the business or had to pay whatever is necessary to be paid.

No, I understand the change in the working capital, but the 480 million to start with the net income, already included some mark-to-market losses in your marketable securities that you presumably have -- should add back. So the fact that the total is 270 million is a pretty low number. Because your 480 million already includes your tax payments and your interest payments. Then you add back your mark-to-market losses on marketable securities, so in fact you should add back a big number there. And then -- okay, and then you deduct from 50 million tax relief, but then this 270 million down 35% on last year, is a surprising number.
I have to take into the detail of this condensed consolidated cash flow statement. What we normally look at is the extensive one, but I'll have to go back and check on this one.
Okay. And so you will come back to me on that or I should call back in the next two days?
That would be great.
Okay.
If you hear nothing from Mr. Geiser, you'll have to call him back.
Okay. Thank you.
Okay.
Next question.
The next question is from Jonathan Herbert, Zadig. Please go ahead, sir.
Yeah, hi. I just wanted to ask you what the status regarding the Comco [Swiss Competition Commission] agreement is? My understanding is it expires in '08?
No, no, no, no, it expires in end of 2010.
Right.
And it's about the kits, the so-called the kits that we will not deliver any more, but we will replace it by finished movements.
So what would be the margin implication moving to finished movements rather than the kits?
I think there could be an improvement in margin.
And on the Assortiments side, do you still have obligation to deliver or not?
No. that's what we just said the kits are the Assortiments.
Assortiments, okay.

If you talk about Nivarox that's something else. Here we don't have any agreement of course. We continue to deliver our Assortiments from Nivarox. The kits from ETA is something else, but the Assortiments are – there is no contract and whatsoever so this is something that continues to continue.
Understood.
There is not a change in the policy.
Understood. Thank you very much for the clarification.
You're welcome. Next question.
The next question is from Aavi Fructus, Atticus. Please, go ahead.

Yeah. Hi. Good afternoon. I have two questions. First one is you compared your market share to Swiss Watch export growth which were 15% in first half in Swiss francs and you did 11% in Swiss francs. So I was wondering how -- what's the correct way to look at that?
And the second one may have just been asked on the 120 million financial charge where it is added back in the cash flow statement please?
Mr. Geiser?
Okay. As I said before, we are going to look into the detailed cash flow statements. I have noted down your name as well. We'll come back to you on this one.

Okay. You know when you look at the federation, this is export numbers. And if I look at my export numbers, how much I have exported with the company in Swiss francs to the other companies, I come to a substantial higher number than your 14 or 15% of the federation.
All right. Okay.

You see you must be careful this is exported product, not sold product, because most of the companies are sending products from Switzerland to their affiliates. So, let's say, Cartier is sending from Switzerland product to the United States, it's in the export numbers but it's not sold products because it goes first to the affiliates of Cartier in the US, the same with us if we deliver something. So if I look at my numbers that I performed in Swiss franc, the turnover that I do in the countries then I see that I have a higher numbers.
So what you are saying is that the market overall at retail level grew less than 15% in Swiss francs, basically.
In Swiss francs, yes.
Okay. Thank you.
Okay. We have no question any more or do we have one?
We have two follow-up questions.
Okay, then we take one of them. If it is a short one, we can take the second one, but then it's over. Mr. Cox is the next?
Yes, the next question is from Mr. Jon Cox...
This is the third time that Mr. Cox is asking a question.

If I have an opportunity, I might as well take it. It's always a pleasure to talk you guys. First question is on electronics; you've obviously talked about a tough environment. I am just wondering if you ever thought about disposing of that overall business as a unit? You've obviously -- you are selling of a little bit of it. I wonder if you've thought of actually getting rid of the whole thing?

Second question is just on – I wonder if you CAN give us some figures on the duty-free, and you've been very kind in the past just to say how the sell out is in the duty-free channels. I know you work with a couple of big the duty-free people. Could one of you just give us some recent data on that? Thank you.

Okay. So I have my all my people traveling around. So I have not the details with me on the paper for duty-free. But again, if I take the comparable basis, the biggest duty-free operator, I compare our brands with the one of the competitors there; we are selling about one-third to double better than the other. That's the situation -- sell out situation in the duty-free operations. But I don't have the exact numbers with me, I am really sorry.
Then about automotive industry, no, we have not a plan to sell everything off. That was your question?
Why bother having the whole division? Why not just get rid of the whole electronics division, it's...
Why? What's with you? Jesus Christ!

First of all, we use a lot of these products for our core business. Don't forget about Quartz watches they need a microchip. Don't forget about the touch screen of Tissot that we developed. We have many, many things that we developed in there that are important for the watch business and that gives add-on business. So Mara is, of course, selling the chips of the very low power and -- to other people. Logitech, for example, or other, but the main usage for it is still watches. So we would be really stupid to sell this division. The technology is geared by watches to help innovation in this field. This is the mission and the reason to have this company.

In a way you are right, we need to -- we are focusing and we are making efforts in this direction. As you have seen we have divested a part of a company for the automotive mechanical activities. So the trend is to focus on the components, which are useful for the watches and useful for the innovation in watches. Okay.

And then you have synergies, of course, in other areas in the world where you can be the leader. As in Logistics, for example, tagging, radio frequency identification, it's a huge field where we can use the watches, but we can also use the know-how of Mara for other products.

The technology of the watches, which is very well suited for portable equipment can be deployed in other fields very successfully as just cited by Mr. Hayek, RFID for example or SIM cards or Access cards.

That what we got rid of was really the mechanical part, automotive industry, that was not interesting for us and gave no potential for developments for the watch industry in the contrary. So that's why we decided we'd rather separate from this area.
Thank you. I wonder if you could just add me to the list as well of those people interested in what's going on in the cash flow statement? Thank you.
Okay. Mr. Geiser will have to make a phone call for all 123 people, now 124 that are participating and then I will line up too so that he gives me also the explanation.
Okay. The last question?
The last question is from Robert Bonte-Friedheim, Select Equity. Please go ahead, sir.

It's a very short one, thank you. And I just -- you mentioned that you have nationality statistics on the sell-through. I'm just wondered if you would give us a sense of how big -- how important Russians are both perhaps globally and in Europe as your customers roughly?

It depends on what brand. Russians are very strong lovers and buyers of Breguet because Breguet is the national hero in Russia, Pushkin already mentioned Breguet, so Breguet is for Russians the nom presulta and then they like very much Blancpain and Omega and recently Swatch watches and let's not forget Longines who is since a long time over there. So I would say the favorite watches of the Russian is definitely Breguet that's the number one and that's in the hit list number one, but more and more you have as well Blancpain, as Glashütte, I have not to forget our German brand, Glashütte and Omega and Swatch.
So if I said overall Russians account for what, 10% of sales maybe?
No!
High?

No, that's too high. That's too high. No, no, no, no. Look, there are still not as many -- you have a lot of millionaires and billionaires in Russia. I agree you could perhaps say this for Breguet. If I take the Breguet watch, I could say, yes, but if you take the Group I must definitely say, no.
Thank you very much.

Thank you. Okay. Thank you everybody. It was nice talking with you. I will head back to Beijing and Mr. Geiser will clarify the points that you wanted to be clarified. I want to repeat, we are looking solidly forward, a very good second half. And we are sure that we will come in with a very good other record year as well as in turnover, as well as in operating profit, but also as well as in net profit. And I don't see a reason why we should not achieve this, this year and also the years to come. Thank you very much. Bye-bye.
Ladies and gentlemen, the conference call is now over, and you may disconnect your telephones. Thank you for joining. Good-bye.
